message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of scaly, erythematous skin surrounding both eyes and mouth suggest atopic dermatitis, which is common in patients with a history of asthma. Expiratory wheezes in the lower lung fields suggest asthma exacerbation, which can be triggered by atopic dermatitis. Viral conjunctivitis does not usually cause skin rash, and impetigo and scalded skin syndrome typically present with more extensive skin involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of itching and rash around the eyes and mouth are characteristic of atopic dermatitis, which is also commonly associated with asthma. The wheezing in the lungs may be related to the patient's asthma but is not indicative of any of the other answer choices.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of recently diagnosed asthma which is commonly seen in patients with atopic dermatitis. The rash around the eyes and mouth also suggests atopic dermatitis. Viral conjunctivitis would cause eye redness and discharge, which is not seen in this case. Impetigo and scalded skin syndrome present with blistering and crusting, which are absent in this patient.

We refer to Mayo Clinic's website for help. The patient's history of asthma and the presence of scaly, erythematous skin surrounding both eyes and his mouth suggests the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis. Impetigo would present with honey-colored crusting lesions, while scalded skin syndrome would present with large blisters and skin peeling. Viral conjunctivitis would present with redness, tearing, and discharge from the eyes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical examination suggest that the most likely diagnosis is Atopic dermatitis, which is commonly associated with asthma. Impetigo would typically present with honey-colored crusts, which are not present in this case. Scalded skin syndrome is rare in children under 5 years of age and would present with diffuse skin involvement and systemic symptoms. Viral conjunctivitis would typically present with bilateral involvement of the eyes and clear or watery discharge, which is not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of asthma and the presence of a pruritic rash around the eyes and mouth suggest atopic dermatitis, which is common in patients with asthma. None of the other options have a consistent presentation with the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the presence of asthma and the itchy rash around the eyes and mouth, suggest atopic dermatitis. Viral conjunctivitis would present with redness and discharge from the eyes. Impetigo would present with crusted, honey-colored lesions. Scalded skin syndrome would present with widespread redness and blistering of the skin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of asthma which is often associated with atopic dermatitis. The scaly, erythematous skin around the eyes and mouth is also typical of atopic dermatitis. The presence of wheezes in the lower lung fields bilaterally suggests asthma exacerbation. Viral conjunctivitis typically presents with conjunctival injection and exudates, while impetigo presents with honey-colored crusting lesions. Scalded skin syndrome presents with diffuse erythema and skin detachment, which are not observed in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of asthma and the presence of scaly, erythematous skin around the eyes and mouth suggest atopic dermatitis, which is often associated with asthma and allergies. Viral conjunctivitis would present with conjunctival inflammation and discharge, while impetigo and scalded skin syndrome involve bullae and crusting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has scaly and erythematous skin around the eyes and mouth indicating atopic dermatitis, which is commonly associated with asthma. The presence of wheezes in the lower lung fields also supports this diagnosis. Viral conjunctivitis would have shown conjunctival exudates, while impetigo and scalded skin syndrome are both characterized by bullous lesions, which are not seen in this patient.
